sentences.text: The task of machine translation -LRB- MT -RRB- evaluation is closely related to the task of sentence-level semantic equivalence classification .
This paper investigates the utility of applying standard MT evaluation methods -LRB- BLEU , NIST , WER and PER -RRB- to building classifiers to predict semantic equivalence and entailment .
We also introduce a novel classification method based on PER which leverages part of speech information of the words contributing to the word matches and non-matches in the sentence .
Our results show that MT evaluation techniques are able to produce useful features for paraphrase classification and to a lesser extent entailment .
Our technique gives a substantial improvement in paraphrase classification accuracy over all of the other models used in the experiments .

The PER metric, a component of standard MT evaluation methods, is investigated for its utility in developing a novel classification method that improves paraphrase classification accuracy. This technique is based on the PER metric and leverages part of speech information to enhance the prediction capabilities of classifiers. Additionally, the broader category of MT evaluation techniques encompasses these standard methods, including NIST, which also contributes to the evaluation of machine translation quality. The technique not only improves paraphrase classification accuracy but also outperforms other models, which are alternative classification models compared in the experiments. Overall, the classifiers developed in this paper utilize these standard evaluation methods to effectively assess and improve the performance of models in the context of paraphrase classification.

The Word Error Rate (WER) and BLEU are both metrics that fall under the broader category of machine translation, which is closely related to sentence-level semantic equivalence classification. The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) also encompasses machine translation within its broader evaluation techniques. MT evaluation techniques are capable of producing useful features that enhance the performance of classifiers, which are designed to predict semantic equivalence and entailment. Furthermore, these techniques leverage part of speech information to improve the novel classification method, a specific type of classification method that aims to boost paraphrase classification accuracy. The words contributing to the word matches and non-matches in a sentence play a crucial role in this evaluation process, as they help identify the relationships between words. Overall, the experiments conducted in this study highlight the effectiveness of these MT evaluation techniques in improving various classification methods.

Part of speech information is related to the words contributing to the word matches and non-matches in the sentence, as it categorizes these words based on their grammatical roles.
